Coal mining is one of the most hazardous occupations in the world. Every year, thousands of miners are injured or killed due to cave-ins, explosions, and exposure to harmful gases like methane and carbon monoxide. In countries with large coal industries, such as China, India, and the United States, these mining fatalities are a tragic but routine part of the energy supply chain.

Beyond the mines, burning coal releases vast amounts of air pollutants, including particulate matter, sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, and heavy metals like mercury. These pollutants contribute to a range of serious health problems, including respiratory diseases, heart disease, lung cancer, and premature death. The World Health Organization and other reputable health organizations have estimated that coal pollution is responsible for hundreds of thousands of premature deaths worldwide each year—far more than the number of deaths ever attributed to nuclear energy.

In contrast, nuclear power has an excellent safety record when measured over the long term. While major nuclear accidents like Chernobyl and Fukushima are rightly remembered for their severity, the overall death toll from these events is relatively small when considered in the context of the vast amount of energy produced by nuclear power over decades. In fact, when you calculate deaths per terawatt-hour of electricity generated, nuclear power ranks among the safest and most life-saving energy sources available.

So, while both energy sources carry risks, the data clearly shows that coal power causes far more deaths per unit of energy than nuclear power. This is why many public health experts and energy analysts advocate for a transition away from coal in favor of cleaner, safer energy sources like nuclear.
